node.title: New in Paperback: ‘First Principles’ and ‘The Searcher’
node.description: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
node.content: ["COLLECTED STORIES, by Shirley Hazzard. Edited by Brigitta Olubas. Foreword by Zo\u00eb Heller. (Picador, 368 pp., $18.) Gathered into a single \u201cimportant and elegant volume,\u201d as the Times critic Dwight Garner called it, the National Book Award-winning Australian American writer\u2019s short stories from the 1960s (before she turned to novels) show \u201ca mature talent,\u201d dispensing \u201cintelligence and irony as if each were fresh herbs in a reticule she kept tied to the belt of her dress.\u201d", "FIRST PRINCIPLES: What America\u2019s Founders Learned From the Greeks and Romans and How That Shaped Our Country, by Thomas E. Ricks. (Harper Perennial, 416 pp., $18.99.) A Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist tracks the intellectual journeys of our first four presidents by focusing on the \u201cunderappreciated\u201d influence that the classics exerted on their thinking.", "MEDIOCRE: The Dangerous Legacy of White Male America, by Ijeoma Oluo. (Seal Press, 336 pp., $17.99.) For many, this cultural, political and historical \u201creckoning\u201d with white men by the author of \u201cSo You Want to Talk About Race\u201d will \u201cappear to be a closed fist,\u201d Brittney Cooper wrote in her review, \u201cbut for the keen eye, it is an open hand,\u201d inviting us to help \u201cpull these men, and the country they are so ready to take with them, back from the precipice.\u201d", "DEARLY: New Poems, by Margaret Atwood. (Ecco, 144 pp., $16.99.) In her 16th collection of poems, many concerned with ecology and time, and \u201chow the present moment, \u2018our too-brief history,\u2019 will look in the future,\u201d our reviewer, Emilia Phillips, observed, we see Atwood \u201cat the height of her poetic powers,\u201d skewering the world with \u201cher fantastically sharp imagination.\u201d", "THE SADDEST WORDS: William Faulkner\u2019s Civil War, by Michael Gorra. (Liveright, 448 pp., $18.95.) Gorra\u2019s \u201cwell-conceived, exhaustively researched book\u201d \u2014 part literary biography, part Civil War history \u2014 is \u201crich in insight,\u201d according to our reviewer, Ayana Mathis, plus \u201ctimely and essential,\u201d as we again confront slavery\u2019s stain and \u201cwho among us should enjoy [citizenship\u2019s] privileges.\u201d", "THE SEARCHER, by Tana French. (Penguin, 464 pp., $18.) \u201cAn audacious departure\u201d for French, this Irish western whose title summons John Ford is \u201cunusually contemplative and visual,\u201d Janet Maslin noted in The Times. Featuring a recently divorced and newly retired Chicago cop, it \u201csteps back to examine the policing powers\u201d French \u201chas traditionally taken for granted.\u201d It\u2019s also a \u201cforay into the natural world, which is so welcome right now.\u201d"]
